item.title: Book Review: Time Loops
item.description: The book Time Loops by Eric Wargo makes a careful argument for the reality of precognitive dreams. My personal interest in this topic has to do with my obsession with time and to an extent, time travel. The author starts the book by summarizing a number of examples of dreams that came true, and closely studies an early dream pioneer named J.W. Dunne who wrote An Experiment with Time. What stands out about Dunne is how he made the distinction between dreaming about events out in the world vs events as experienced by the future self.

item.title: Qubits and the Multiverse: how to ğšğš’ğš-ğš‹ğš›ğšŠğš—ğšŒğš‘ your life
item.description: Have you ever had a decision that was hard to make because both sides of the decision were great in their own way? Where you stress over the decision and wish you could split into two copies of yourself? Some decision theorists recommend flipping a coin, but there is a better way. Coins are made of lots of atoms, and many of those atoms are entangled with each other and with the environment.
